title: The Naming Ritual
story: Welcome, young Code Mage! The village elder approaches you with an ancient scroll. "To begin your journey, you must learn the first spell of our craft - the Variable Declaration. Declare a string variable called 'heroName' and bind it to the name 'Aria'."
starterCode: // Declare a string variable called 'heroName' and assign it the value "Aria"
hints: In C#, we declare variables with: type name = value;
Text values are called 'strings' and need double quotes
The full syntax is: string heroName = "Aria";

steps.explanation: In programming, a VARIABLE is like a labeled box where you can store information. Just like you might label a box 'Photos' to store pictures, you give variables names to store data.
steps.tip: Think of a variable as a sticky note with a name on it, attached to a value.

steps.explanation: In C#, every variable has a TYPE that tells the computer what kind of data it holds. For text (words, sentences, names), we use the type 'string'.
steps.tip: The word 'string' refers to a 'string of characters' - letters connected together!

steps.explanation:
To create a variable, you write: TYPE NAME = VALUE;

The equals sign (=) means 'assign this value to this variable'.
steps.tip: The semicolon (;) at the end tells C# that your statement is complete.

steps.explanation: String values MUST be wrapped in double quotes ("). This tells C# where the text starts and ends.
steps.codeOutput: The variable 'greeting' now holds: Hello World
steps.tip: Without quotes, C# would think you're referring to other variables named Hello and World!

steps.explanation: Now you're ready! Create a string variable named 'heroName' and give it the value "Aria". Remember: type, name, equals, value in quotes, semicolon!
steps.tip: Copy this pattern exactly - just make sure to use the name 'heroName' and the value "Aria".

exploration.introduction: Let's play with string variables! Try running each example, then modify the code to see what happens.

examples.title: Creating a String Variable
examples.explanation:
This is the basic pattern for creating a string variable. The variable 'message' holds the text "Hello!" and we print it out.

Try changing "Hello!" to something else and run the code!

examples.title: Variables Can Be Changed
examples.explanation:
Once you create a variable, you can change its value later. Notice we don't write 'string' again - the variable already exists!

Try adding a third line that changes 'name' to your own name.

examples.title: Combining Strings
examples.explanation:
You can combine strings using the + operator. This is called 'concatenation'.

Try changing the greeting or the name!
